unnormalised: The Delhi Jal Board (DJB) just announced revised water tariffs, and folks are already buzzing about how it'll hit their pockets. Starting 01/07/2024, if you're gulping down more than 20,000 liters a month, brace yourselves for a hike. They're saying it's to encourage responsible water usage, but many families are worried, especially with the summer heat.
normalised: The Delhi Jal Board (D-J-B) just announced revised water tariffs, and folks are already buzzing about how it will hit their pockets. Starting first July two thousand and twenty four, if you are gulping down more than twenty thousand liters a month, brace yourselves for a hike. They are saying it is to encourage responsible water usage, but many families are worried, especially with the summer heat.

unnormalised: Previously, households consuming up to 20k liters got a waiver, effectively paying ₹0. Now, anything over that will be charged on a slab basis. So, if your bill was around ₹500 before, expect it to jump, maybe even double, depending on your usage. Some residents are already grumbling about fixing leaky pipes and shortening showers.
normalised: Previously, households consuming up to twenty thousand liters got a waiver, effectively paying rupee zero. Now, anything over that will be charged on a slab basis. So, if your bill was around rupee five hundred before, expect it to jump, maybe even double, depending on your usage. Some residents are already grumbling about fixing leaky pipes and shortening showers.

unnormalised: The DJB claims the move is necessary to cover operational costs and improve infrastructure. They're aiming to invest ₹1000 crore in upgrading water treatment plants and pipelines. But some critics are pointing fingers, saying the hike disproportionately affects middle-class families, especially those in older colonies where water wastage is often due to outdated infrastructure.
normalised: The D-J-B claims the move is necessary to cover operational costs and improve infrastructure. They are aiming to invest rupee one thousand crore in upgrading water treatment plants and pipelines. But some critics are pointing fingers, saying the hike disproportionately affects middle-class families, especially those in older colonies where water wastage is often due to outdated infrastructure.

unnormalised: Ultimately, it's all about balancing the books and keeping the water flowing. Whether the new tariffs will actually lead to conservation or just create bigger bills remains to be seen. Keep an eye on your next DJB bill, folks, and maybe consider investing in some water-saving showerheads!
